title: Association Between Sleep Duration and Anxiety in US Adults: A Nationally Representative Cross-Sectional Study
authors: Xing Wang, Yunhui Zhong, Rui Wang, Dongdong Zhang, Yihan Li, Yi Pan, Yibo Li
relevance_note: Quantifies the relationship between sleep duration and anxiety using a large, representative US adult sample and provides quantitative reports.

title: Sleep Quality and its Relationship to Mental Health, Physical Health, and Health Behaviors Among Young Adults with Serious Mental Illness Enrolled in a Lifestyle Intervention Trial
authors: Kelly A. Aschbrenner, John A. Naslund, Jessica K. Salwen-Deremer, Julia Browne, Stephen J. Bartels, Rosemarie S. Wolfe, Haiyi Xie, Kim T. Mueser
relevance_note: Uses the PSQI to examine sleep quality in young adults with serious mental illness; finds significant association between poor sleep quality and depressive symptoms (β = .438, p < .001) but not with physical health or health behaviors.

title: Which Is More Important for Health: Sleep Quantity or Sleep Quality?
relevance_note: Review article examining whether sleep quantity or quality is more important for health; concludes that sleep quality is superior to sleep quantity as an index for assessing sleep and health outcomes.

title: Dissociable effects of self-reported daily sleep duration on high-level cognitive abilities
authors: Conor J. Wild, Emily S. Nichols, Michael E. Battista, Bobby Stojanoski, Adrian M. Owen
relevance_note: Large-scale study showing that sleep duration has a U-shaped relationship with cognitive performance, with optimal performance at 7-8 hours; too much or too little sleep both impair reasoning and verbal abilities.

title: Relationship between night-sleep duration and risk for depression in middle-aged and older adults
authors: Xin-lin Li, Jiayin Wei, Xinying Zhang, Zhuo Meng, Wentao Zhu
relevance_note: Dose-response meta-analysis showing a U-shaped association between night-sleep duration and depression risk in middle-aged and older adults, with 7 hours being optimal.

title: Associations between sleep duration and depression, mental health, physical health, and general health in U.S. adults: A population-based study
authors: Mojisola Fasokun, Oluwasegun Akinyemi, Fadeke Ogunyankin, Phiwinhlanhla Ndebele-Ngwenya, Kaelyn Gordon, Seun Ikugbayigbe, Uzoamaka Nwosu, Mariam Michael, Kakra Hughes, Temitope Ogundare
relevance_note: Large US population-based study demonstrating higher depression incidence and worse health outcomes for both short and long sleepers versus 6-8 hours of sleep.

title: Sleep duration, sleep quality, and biomarkers of inflammation in a Taiwanese population
authors: Jennifer B. Dowd, Noreen Goldman, Maxine Weinstein
relevance_note: Links objectively measured sleep duration/quality with inflammatory biomarkers such as CRP and IL-6 in adults.

title: The effect of sleep and its restriction on selected inflammatory parameters
authors: Marcin Sochal, Marta Ditmer, Szymon Turkiewicz, Filip Karuga, Piotr Białasiewicz, Agata Gabryelska
relevance_note: Experimental sleep restriction study relating polysomnographic sleep continuity measures to immune and inflammatory indices.

title: Sleep regularity and mortality: a prospective analysis in the UK Biobank
authors: Faris M. Zuraikat, Brooke Aggarwal, Sanja Jelic, Marie-Pierre St-Onge
relevance_note: Shows that sleep regularity index predicts all-cause and cause-specific mortality better than average sleep duration.

title: Regular sleep patterns, not just duration, critical for mental health
authors: Dong-Run Li, Zheng-Xuan Li, Ming-Hui Li, Bang-Quan Liu, Qian Fang, Jia-Cheng Liu, Wen-Rui Zheng, Ting-Ting Gong, Shan-Yan Gao, Qi-Jun Wu
relevance_note: In a large adult cohort, higher sleep regularity is associated with substantially lower depression and anxiety risk, independent of total sleep hours.

title: The adverse impact of excessive smartphone screen-time on sleep quality among young adults: A prospective cohort
authors: Daneyal Arshad, Usaid Munir Joyia, Sadaf Fatima, Noor Khalid, Anser Ikram Rishi, Naimat Ullah Abdul Rahim, Syed Faheem Bukhari, Gulfam Khan Shairwani, Ahmed Salmaan
relevance_note: Prospective cohort study linking objectively measured daily smartphone screen time with higher odds of poor sleep quality (PSQI) in young adults.

title: Associations of sleep pattern, sleep duration, bedtime, rising time and cardiovascular disease: Data from NHANES (2017-2020)
authors: Xiao Zhang, Dongling Wang, Jiangang Liu
relevance_note: Shows dose-response associations between sleep patterns, duration, timing and cardiovascular disease risk using nationally representative US data.

title: Effect of melatonin supplementation on sleep quality: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials
authors: Gholami Fatemeh, Moradi Sajjad, Rasaei Niluofar, Soveid Neda, Setayesh Leila, Mirzaei Khadijeh
relevance_note: Meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials indicating melatonin significantly improves sleep quality (e.g., PSQI scores) compared with control.

title: Sleep regularity and duration are associated with depression severity in a nationally representative United States sample
authors: Katherine A. Maki, Li Yang, Nicole L. Farmer, Shreya Papneja, Gwenyth R. Wallen, Jennifer L. Barb
relevance_note: Shows that lower sleep regularity and shorter sleep are linked to higher depression scores, with stronger effects in women and those using tobacco/cannabis.

title: Cognitive Behavioral Insomnia Therapy for Those With Insomnia and Depression: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial
authors: Colleen E. Carney, Jack D. Edinger, Maragatha Kuchibhatla, Angela M. Lachowski, Olya Bogouslavsky, Andrew D. Krystal, Colin M. Shapiro
relevance_note: Randomized trial demonstrating that CBT for insomnia combined with antidepressant medication improves both objective sleep and depression outcomes in comorbid patients.

title: Associations Between Both Smartphone Addiction and Objectively Measured Smartphone Use and Sleep Quality and Duration Among University Students: Cross-Sectional Study
authors: Jian Yin, Xuanyi Tang, Zeshi Liu, Yangyang Gong, Hui Yang, Yanping Zhang
relevance_note: Cross-sectional study showing dose-response associations between both smartphone addiction scores and objectively measured screen time with poor sleep quality and shorter duration in university students.
